title: How can nothing exist without something? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think you are envisioning a sort of yin and yang scenario but that's not necessarily the case here. True NO-Thing is the absence of both yin and yang. Even the concept of a void dosen't truly capture the esence of true NO-Thing as a void implies the absence of SOME-Thing. Not even the concept of NO-Thing can exist in true NO-Thing. Something can not exist in true NO-Thing AND nothing can not exist in true NO-thing. It is a difficult concept and the closest I can come to comprehending it is trying to envision what it was like before i was born.

Light and dark are not opposites, darkness is the absence of light. Dark does not require light in order to be a real concept. Sound and silence are not opposites, silence is the absence of sound. Silence does not require sound in order to exist. concept. However, nether darkness nor silence is a thing. It’s just a word to define the absence of a thing. The same holds true for something vs nothing. Something can exist. But “nothing” does not have an “existence”. It is simply the absence of something (anything).

Nothing doesn't exist.  Only something exists.  Nothing is not something.   I've been all around the world and I've never seen nothing.  I've imagined it, but then I've imagined pink unicorns too.    I'm not sure what else to say to satisfy Quora.  This seems all that needs to be said about nothing.    Don't reify it.  Nothing is just the absence of something.   You can use it as a mathematical concept or for meditation.  But you can't actually find it.  It doesn't actually exist.

What? I don't think that that question makes sense. Strictly speaking, nothing doesn't exist. Anything that existed would have to be something. So given that it's a misconception to assert that nothing exists at all, the question of how it could exist without something doesn't arise.

Update:Where there is nothing EVERYTHING is possible (though not guaranteed) since there is no pre-condition. Anything might enter from outside a bounded/finite void or if the extent of nothingness is total / infinite then void is continuous and immutable. Previous answer:This is a misuse of language. This is not a noun describing an object "nothing" as this is the antithesis of existing. Like a female man. Your question is ( deliberately ) flawed by the choice if words and at any deeper level. Had you phrased it "is anything possible where there is nothing?" If would have had a very straightforward answer.
